column1:
On September 17::: 1936::: the bells that now ring out across U-M’s central campus from Burton Tower were delivered to Ann Arbor. 🔔 #ThrowbackThursday
📸: Ann Arbor District Library
column3:
That was the same year (1936) that saw my late father arriving at the University of Michigan to study Engineering. He enjoyed hearing the bells::: during his time there. He finished his Junior year::: before being taken by the Army and commissioned as a 2nd Lt. He was a Captain leading troops during the Normandy Invasion and later battles of WWII. After the war ended::: he returned to U of M and finished his degree in 1946. He later was one of the pioneering NASA Apollo Engineers::: who helped in designing rocket engines for Lunar Landings and a number of subsequent NASA projects. He came to Ann Arbor from humble roots and went on to lead a full life::: becoming a U.S. Army Colonel and senior instructor at Army Command and General Staff College::: to go along with his accomplishiment
s as an engineer and NASA rocket scientist.

column48:
As a parent of an OOS freshman and marching band member (from California where we are still pretty much locked down)::: there are so many pieces to this puzzle. One is that football and basketball pay for almost ALL other sports. It is not the ticket sales::: it is the TV package. So if tailgating is not allowed::: and no fans or even students attend games::: the big money TV still comes in. When the PAC12 announced no Fall sports::: Stanford University::: the school with the most NCAA championships in all sports::: immediately eliminated::: permanently::: about 6 sports::: including men's volleyball which they are perennial championship contenders. That is a shame for all kids.

So while my better judgment tells this is probably not the best move for long term control of the virus::: having any season might just save the lacrosse or field hockey teams.

How do you prepare artists for a future with deserted performance venues::: reduced audiences::: & budget cuts? Student teams and faculty from across campus have been exploring the possibilities of learning::: designing::: and performing in digital spaces. myumi.ch/ovM5x #UMichArts

Each year in memory of those who lost their lives on September 11::: 2001::: members of U-M’s ROTC programs stand guard at the flagpole on the Central Campus Diag as part of a memorial vigil.
column3:
19 years ago::: this Wolverine was in shock as I evacuated my office in Pittsburgh and went to retrieve my 2 year old at daycare.
I had been alerted by friends that there was a plane ( Flight 93) that may be headed for Pittsburgh after the twin towers had been hit.
It was that day:::feeling helpless and wanting to do anything to help and not feel so useless::: the concept of Homefront Hugs was born.

We began one month later on 10/11/01 in honor of our heroes on the frontlines and our nation as we stood united::: one nation::: ready to heal and support our heroes without conditions. My Jewish grandfather had taught me so much about love against hate and honoring our WWII troops who saved so many::: this was in honor of all our heroes.

We have lost too many to suicide since 9/11 and every day we try to make a difference one hero at Homefront Hugs Foundation

Remembering all those lost today 19 years ago::: and how our country came together with allies worldwide. There was no room for hate or bitterness against any religion or group.

Http://
HomefrontHugs.or
g/NeverForget

I was holding my little boy::: wondering how I would bring some meaning to this one day. His Daddy was a pilot in the Air Force. I wanted him to understand what heroes do. I wanted him not to hate but to help. And so it began.

We need to remember this again during this pandemic. Together we heal and get through this if we reject the divisions. Your help is gratefully accepted if you can donate or volunteer.

column1: Originally constructed in 1916::: the Michigan Union has been a popular gathering space and a common area for U-M students. Earlier this year::: the Union reopened its doors to the U-M community following an 18-month-long renovation process::: welcoming everyone back into the historic space and allowing them to enjoy the new amenities::: including an enclosed indoor courtyard. After having to close its doors again in March due to #COVID19::: the Union opened again this week ahead of this fall's public health-informed fall semester. #ThrowbackThursday #URecord myumi.ch/kxD3k

column3:
So... discussing democracy... being an institution of higher learning... does that mean that EVERYONE's opinon is included? Or only those that agree with the institutional alignment? Will those that go against the alignment of the institution be shunned::: expelled::: or fired like other major universities around the country? Will a person's race protect or hinder their opinions? (Let's not let the influence of social media get involved...)

Now is the time to protect ALL free speech on campus::: not just the speech of those who the University agrees with. Remember this::: the Constitutional rights of one end::: where the Constitutional rights of others are compromised or threatened.

Democracy is best preserved when both sides of an argument can carry on a civil discussion::: where each side actually analyzes the arguments put before them::: and not just cast them off as irrelevent. Will that be allowed to happen? Or will the mediators allow one side to shut the other out::: and not let them table their opinions?

They weren’t given the same opportunities at ownership of land::: education or jobs. Even as recent as the 1950s Jim Crow laws and inequality were still in place. We must educate ourselves and our children to ensure history doesn’t ever repeat itself and to finally make sure all people really are treated equally.

I completely reject the notion that anyone who points out the hypocrisies and injustices in American society past or present is branded an “America Hater.”

Anyone with a rudimentary knowledge of American history understands that white male supremacy has been the defining feature of America for four centuries.

And if we are to overcome our racism and misogyny and create a country where true equality exists in fact and not only in words::: we have to speak the truth to ourselves as well as each other. That is the definition of patriotism.

column5:
Systemic racism is real. Education is key. When slavery ended policies were put in place not to provide education or jobs. As time went on Black people could only buy houses in certain neighborhoods (redlining) even in the 1970s. Mortgage rates were different for Black people. Funding for schools even to this day is different for poor black neighborhoods making education different. There’s quite a bit of material out there. Driving While Black by Gretchen Sorin is a great book about the history of civil rights. If reading isn’t your thing 1619 is a very informative podcast.
History isn’t taught accurately so many people are unaware of what really happened.

column1: In late June 1898::: the flagpole from the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago was moved to Ann Arbor and installed on the Diag. #ThrowbackThursday

column6:
"The flagpole was one of the items the university obtained from the World’s Columbian Exposition::: held in 1893 in Chicago. A tremendous affair of international importance::: the exposition celebrated the 400th anniversary of Columbus’s discovery of the New World (but opened a year late::: hence 1893 not 1892). Other major items that the university acquired from the Expo were the Frieze Memorial Organ::: now in Hill Auditorium::: and two large murals or lunettes by Gari Melchers::: now in the main reading room of Hatcher Library."

As sugar and flour disappear from grocery shelves almost as quickly as hand sanitizer and toilet paper::: Assistant Professor Monica Dus wonders what effect eating all this sugar will have on our brains.

Why We Do Science | U-M LSA U-M College of LSA
column3: I was ready to be annoyed at this article::: and prepared to be "lectured at" for gravitating to comfort foods. Turns out::: Dr. Dus has a pretty philosophical approach to our emotional eating: "I feel like people should just be kind to themselves. If we were wired to find comfort in sugar::: this is the time to give in to biology and find comfort. This isn’t the time to worry about gaining a few pounds. A few pounds are definitely not going to hurt anybody. My advice would be to be kind to yourself and those around you instead."
column4: Interestingly::: I heard a report on the radio while in the car that people actually ate healthier during the lockdowns than normal. Foods in restaurants contain more sugar::: salt::: fats::: and calories than do homemade meals and snacks. Sorry::: I don't remember who the report was from.

University of Michigan - you keep posting these. You have thousands of comments. Thousands of staff and faculty who are concerned. Thousands of young 20-30 year olds::: who are now testing positive. Thousands of out-of-state students who are currently living in the hotbeds of this country who are planning on coming to the U. Are you even readings or listening or reading the feedback? What is your plan for students who are anti-maskers off campus? The ones who come into our town and throw kickbacks? Is there a plan for that? Are you going to hold them to the same guidelines? Because that's a miserable experience for a first-year student.

Your plan protects you. Not our city. Not us. Where is your concern for the city? I know this benefits you. If the students come back::: you'll have more medical research on COVID. If the students come back::: you can thrive as an industry. You're not as liberal as you claim if you're taking the side of the president and DeVos::: and telling us that they're coming back. You are part of the reason why the public school can't go back. They can't risk that exposure that your students will bring.

You're in a lose-lose situation::: I know that. But I want to go back again to ask you::: did you even ask your community?

column107:
I understand everyone’s excitement to have the option of returning to campus::: but I don’t know how it will be possible to practically implement all these changes. There are around 44:::000 students on campus in any given term. Yes::: some will choose to learn entirely remotely and some will take hybrid courses. But for however many students live on campus or choose in person instruction::: I don’t trust in their compliance with these protocols::: whether that be due to poor judgment::: their political views::: or ignorance.

Even when classes went remote in March after fears about coronavirus became more serious::: I remember seeing students out partying—how are these measures going to counteract that? All it takes is one student who is sick attending a frat party::: having too much to drink::: taking off their mask::: and suddenly tons of people may be made sick.

And just to mention::: I’m sure many students will follow these guidelines and comply with protocol. The problem is the ones who don’t::: who may ruin it for everyone else. I have seen flagrant disregard of social distancing guidelines by adults in Michigan::: so I have my reservations about how college students will handle it.

column10:
Plans for K-12 and higher ed to reopen are largely based on the governor's plan::: but both parties of big business support opening back up regardless of containment of the virus. Otherwise why would Whitmer have already authorized the reopening of non-essential auto manufacturing which occurs in areas of the state recognized by her own task force as still level 3::: i.e. not yet the "Improving" of Level 4? We are being confronted with a bipartisan adoption of the unscientific (and murderous) "herd immunity" strategy::: which is no strategy at all::: literally. What is required before reopening schools::: according to multiple scientific studies and leading public health authorities as this letter from a Biology teacher so thoroghly points out::: (https://
www.wsws.org/en/
articles/2020/
05/29/
lett-m29.html)::: is continued sheltering in place with distance learning::: combined with universal weekly testing::: plus contact tracing and quarantining. Anything short of this will bring new surges as is already happening in areas of the world where schools reopened prematurely and subsequently had to be closed (France::: South Korea::: Denmark) and auto plants in the US. None of these requirements are being met anywhere in the US.

column1:
Every fall::: millions of monarch butterflies — each weighing less than a gram — fly up to 2:::500 miles to reach specific sites in the states of Mexico and Michoacán::: where they spend the winter huddled together on trees. But do we know just how they do it? University of Michigan College of Literature::: Science::: and the Arts professor D. André Green wants to find out.

LSA.UMICH.EDU
Rewriting the Monarch Story | U-M LSA U-M College of LSA
